discussion.content:
All the answers are terrible but "C" could be remotely possible!
If the user has added something to the cloned Vm that does not exist on the appvol capture VM then it has moved away from the base image we captured. If ONLY some of the apps are not working then this is the only possible explanation and a refresh would bring it back to base we started from. remember it said SOME OF THE USERS...

For me, the only viable answer is D. 

 A. I can't see how Answer A would provide a solution to poorly performing App Volumes.
 B. As tempting as this sounds, the provisioning VM used for creating your App Volumes should resemble your Host VDI Master Image as closely as possible : https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-App-Volumes/4/com.vmware.appvolumes.admin.doc/GUID-BCC67C19-AC5C-4D25-9F1B-9BE8536A2909.html
C. Again, can't see how this will help apart from a token troubleshooting step.
D. This seems to be the only viable option and indeed what I have found in my own testing is that App Volumes works best when you group applications together into a single App Volume and restrict access to these apps via other technologies (such as FSLogix App Masking, UEM application blocking etc.) VMware even say that they have only tested a maximum of 5 app volumes mounted to any single VDI VM: https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/67354

comments.content:
So wrong. 
"Provision the AppStacks on a clean base image, that is a virtual machine, that closely resembles the target environment to which you later plan to deploy the AppStack.

For example, the provisioning virtual machine and the target should be at the same patch and service pack level. If you have included applications in the base image, they should also be present in the provisioning virtual machine". 
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-App-Volumes/2.18/com.vmware.appvolumes.admin.doc/GUID-85561285-9243-444F-AD1D-0A8E1CD9589A.html

discussion.content: The answer is B, agree with rfelipe... the provisioning machine needs to be as vanilla as possible but the correct OS the end users will be using.
test comment
Why need to update the App Volumes Agent in the golden master image? The recommendation is to use a vanilla iamge, so in my opinion it should be B

comments.content:
B cant be right, the recommendation from VMware is 
The golden image must have the required OS, the necessary updates and service packs, and core applications common to all user desktops.
https://techzone.vmware.com/resource/reviewers-guide-vmware-app-volumes

Refresh is supported for instant clones, so my guess is answer C

choices.C: Refresh the Horizon desktop VMs of the users experiencing the issues.
choices.B: Install a new copy of the same Windows operating system without any updates, patches, or service packs, and use it as the App Volumes capture VM.
choices.D: Capture each application in a single App Stack and assign each user the correct application using Identity Manager.
choices.A: Update the App Volumes Agent in the golden master image, then delete and redeploy the Horizon desktops of the users experiencing issues.

questions.question_text:
A company wants to migrate end user applications to VMware App Volumes. The IT team creates five App Stacks using a Windows desktop VM deployed from a golden master image used for all Horizon desktop pools. Some users experience application failures with a few applications in some of the App Stacks.
What can the IT team do to resolve these application issues?

questions.question_text:
A cloud pod architecture has been proposed for a customer with two data centers available in two cities 1700 Miles apart. The data centers are connected using
WAN links with sophisticated security requirements and firewall rules.
A WAN maintenance vendor has been contacted to add exceptions to meet cloud pod architecture requirements. The number of ports to be opened to enable datacenter to datacenter communication should stay at a minimum number.
Which two communication ports are required by the WAN maintenance vendor? (Choose two.)

A customer is looking to implement a VMware solution with these requirements:
✑ Support for 200 call center employees on a single 8-hour shift
✑ Application access through physical Windows 7 desktops
✑ Restrict access to only these applications: Google Chrome, FileZilla (an open source FTP application), and a custom in-house client-server call center application
An architect is tasked with determining the lowest cost license solution that will meet the customer's requirements.
Which solution should the architect choose?

discussion.content:
B
https://www.vmware.com/content/dam/digitalmarketing/vmware/en/pdf/whitepaper/vmw-workspace-one-horizon-uselet.pdf

yon need horizon 7 advance or enterprise.
nominal are cheaper then concurrent. you have only 1 shift.
If it's a single 8-hour shift then 200 Named users would be the most cost-effective.

A
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Horizon-7/7.0/com.vmware.horizon-view.desktops.doc/GUID-78B4769E-CC4C-435F-A8D4-79CD70527B08.html

I believe the answer is "A". 

Although it is possible to redirect URL content in both directions, the requirements in the question specifically says: "Sales personnel however will be able to access links from email or other documents from their VDI sessions." which makes me think that the URLs opened within the VDI session should be redirected to their client.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Horizon-7/7.13/horizon-remote-desktop-features/GUID-AD2CA3C1-6C93-491F-B199-1FD8C23271B9.html

Very tricky question, but let's read manual
With agent-to-client redirection, Horizon Agent sends the URL to Horizon Client, which opens the default application for the protocol in the URL.
With client-to-agent redirection, Horizon Client opens a remote desktop or published application to handle a URL link that a user clicks on the client. If a remote desktop is opened, the default application for the protocol in the URL processes the URL. If a published application is opened, the published application processes the URL.
So I will go with B "Install View Client with URL redirection enabled." because question is about VDI desktop, not an application
 https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Horizon-7/7.6/horizon-remote-desktop-features/GUID-6E24F6BE-D5D2-4D73-9A9A-0E87C9849B9E.html
"A", as it is an AGENT option with GPO to control URL redirection
I will choose A. But I think It need A and B

I chose B. URL redirection will allow a link in the VDI session to open on the client browser and keep the 'no internet' restriction in VDI. Client drive redirection doesn't cover URL links that may be in emails or documents.

 https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Horizon-7/7.6/horizon-remote-desktop-features/GUID-AD2CA3C1-6C93-491F-B199-1FD8C23271B9.html

choices.B: Install View Client with URL redirection enabled.
choices.A: Install View Agent with URL redirection enabled.

questions.question_text:
A company wants to allow sales personnel to use laptops to access the internal VDI. Due to security constraints, VDI desktop pools for travelers will not be granted access to the Internet. Sales personnel however will be able to access links from email or other documents from their VDI sessions.
What can be implemented to meet these requirements?

A customer has made the decision to implement App Volumes. The customer has two data centers for High Availability. VMware recommends two different deployment modes for App Volumes in a multi-site implementation.
Which two requirements are common to all of the models? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
I think I was wrong. The answer is BC
There are two architectural options for deploying App Volumes across multiple sites:

Separate instances per site with each site having a separate database
A stretched instance using a clustered database with Microsoft SQL AlwaysOn
if use stretched instance with Microsoft SQL AlwaysOn ,the entilements can also copy to second site. so i think the common are appvolume replication and appvolume manager in each site.

comments.content:
https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2107127
This kb show how to manual copy appstack 。The SQL can use An Always On availability group achieves automatic failover. Both App Volumes Manager servers point to the availability group listener for the SQL Server. 。So A is not right. Manual copy appstack,so C is needed .

discussion.content: I think BD appstack can copy by appvolume manager or manual 。But the entitlements both need to be manual 。

Hear me out. They ask for 2 deployment models... I can only find one which is replicating entitlements and appstacks between sites. The question asks what 2 requirements are common? Wat if the other mode of deployment was to manually create appstacks twice and entitlements? Than the things that are in common are that you need to deploy a SQL cluster and one app volumes manager per site for either and automated or a manual replication. AB

CD is correct. "Replication of the AppStacks between sites can be automated, but any entitlements to AppStacks must be replicated in both sites."
https://blogs.vmware.com/euc/2017/11/vmware-horizon-7-enterprise-edition-multi-site-reference-architecture-updated.html
Apologies, I meant CD and not BC. CD is the tasks that needs to be performed

BC is correct as per Appvol reference architecture paper. A & B are min infrastructure requirement for any appvol installation. BC are the two tasks we need to perform to make appstacks and assignments identical on both sites
I think BC

choices.B: Deploy a minimum of one App Volumes manager in each site.
